item.title: July 27, 2176
item.description:
We drag Dr. No and a couple of his flunkies up to Mittens’ penthouse apartment. He’s spitting venom, absolutely furious, but that’s all he can do. It’s not too hard to get the information from him: his lab is in a recycling plant on the edge of Containment Zone 9, at the edge of the Tombs. They’re getting pressure from the Combinaught and the Joe Pox syndicates to share, but it hasn’t broken out into a full-fledged gang war. The deal was brokered via anonymous dropoff; they weren’t expecting the extra heat that showed up. The farm’s in the Southside NoGo, which is a war zone. It’s also highly suspected of being the HQ of the ADO Fifth—the Cybrid militia.
Moto’s got some information on the kidnap job. That the kids aren’t being ransomed is bad—it means there was some other reason they were kidnapped. That also means there are a limited number of locations they could be held: primarily other corpo campuses. These kids are inheritors; if it were proven another corp took them, that could mean an intercorporate war. In the chaos of the A-Spire, they dropped off the grid completely. No one’s touched their cred accounts or social media at all.
The only thing we know for sure is that there’s an agent with some hot information on Wutani, and the information is legit, because Wutani Internal Security’s after them. We can’t figure out why Wutani’s involved, but it’s not the first time we’ve run into Wutani sniffing around biotech. Moto goes into the Wutani corporate espionage data we picked up from the Moderns—it’s accounting data. Someone in Wutani’s committing accounting fraud; a guy named Emiliano Delacourt, a forensic accountant, was looking into it. The Moderns had an idea of who was committing the fraud. Dr. Lila Ortiz, the Moderns’ drug designer, might know; George Fyron, the manager of the Spire, might also know. Or, even better, we could call in a favor from Rico Silva, since he owes us for helping hold off the HouTex mercs.
Rico’s happy to put us in touch with Dr. Ortiz, via secure commlink in Obscura. The glands purchased were basal gland templates, which are used for more exotic genetics. Such as people who have been genetically improved. She’s designed a few very customized glands using basal templates; the client in question didn’t want the experience of the gland per se. They wanted the experience of the gland as felt by an individual. In other words, the basal templates are used to create single-user glands that can replicate the experience of one person to another. Bespoke dope. We can’t figure out an angle.
Rico’s able to send us surveillance footage of the kids getting taken. Lucky 13’s group goes down like the punks they are; the other group holds out longer, but eventually get taken out themselves. The kidnapper is Pumpkin Jack, a known serial killer, and someone who will take jobs for maintenance. Looks like his blades were loaded with a neurotoxin, enough to take the kids down but not kill them. He’s taking advantage of the chaos to get the kids… and he’s got help. Synths—old, out of date Wutani synths. It’s too much Wutani—it looks like someone inside Wutani skimming resources for a personal project. It looks like we’re going to have to pony up for the agent’s information. We can also poke around the Dollhouse, a clearing-house for synths and restricted chrome.
The agent wants hard cash, nothing traceable, that can be transferred elsewhere. Moto sets Obscura as the meet place; it’s a good place for anonymous meets. We settle in: Moto gets the message “Courier enroute; code FN.” The courier is only about 4 feet tall, with limbs of the wrong shape—because it’s a giant raven. His name is Full Nelson. Moto passes the money to FN, and FN passes back a protein drive.
The data dump: Project Trioseros is where the money’s going. It’s an attempt to create a drug to biomimic security systems. The project is completely outside the corporate structure except for one small funnel for money and logistics. The reports on the project are completely fake—most likely, this is a personal project using the corp for cover. The name on the project is David Franklin Clavell. And the agent who sold us the data—Emiliano Delacourt, the forensic accountant. The reason Delacourt’s running? A Wutani exec pursuing a personal project that’s been kept under the radar outranks a forensic accountant who might make the company look bad, even if it uncovers wrongdoing. They’ve found something in the failed experiments that destroys the mRNA in glands, referred to as ‘Ruiner’. It’s a virus that would essentially destroy glands. Attica narrows possible sites down to three: Black Helix, Neovana, and Null Street.
Neovana’s a neurocropolis, where the digitized deceased rest. Guarded by corporate monks. Black Helix is a reskinning lab. Null Street is 10 blocks of a “cogito-libertarian paradise”. Null Street is our likeliest contender—no one cares what goes on in there. They’ve got a flight of drones that keeps out satellite observation. They’re beyond paranoid. But, paradoxically, that might be our way in.
Mittens needs us to go into NoGo to the Paradise Line, very hush-hush, very sneak, and talk to Seven-Jim. Seven-Jim is the militant head of the Animal Technological Intervention Directive. Seven-Jim is going to raid the gland farm—but he plans to completely burn it out, whether or not they’re recoverable. She’d like us to try and talk Seven-Jim into a more nuanced approach, and fast…

item.title: August 1, 2176
item.description:
The Butler has set us up with someone to help—she’s a synth, N3M-3515. She was built as an intelligent, self-directing synth that snapped when her favorite tech (that named her “Nemesis”) was killed by Weytani security. Moto gets into the synths’ cyberware and uncovers the security access protocols: door codes, locations of other synths in the building, maps, etc. Then he hacks their comms.
Silently, the team moves into position. Attica takes her target out first with a single strike. Spider and Firefox take out the second; this one’s tougher. Nemesis has trouble with the third one; despite her skill, it struggles. Graves comes in clutch and pops it from above. We take the stairs down; after Attica takes out the stairs guard, we split in two groups. Attica, Gloria and Spider head to the labs; Firefox, Nemesis and Graves go after Clavell.
The first two lab rooms are easy; the synths working here are non-combat models and fold beneath a threat of force.
Nemesis and Firefox walk into Clavell’s office. “Oh, an Amp! So exciting!” He looks at Nemesis. “I helped design your brain. In a way, I suppose I’m one of your fathers.” Nemesis activates her shock fists and Firefox mentally compels him to shut his mouth. Firefox lays it out for him: we’re here to take the children back, and he can either let them go or we can burn the whole place down with him in it. He starts to say that we can have the males, but it’s going to take some time to retrieve the women. (He’s perversely fascinated by the female form.) That’s when he twitches and a different voice comes from his throat: it’s Zaid, one of the girls we’re here to rescue. Somehow, Clavell has extracted the memory and personality engrams and injected it into himself. This is far beyond glands. He says she was irretrievably damaged by the process; Firefox hopes she can do something. "Moto comes on the network. “We’ve got movement; Clavell must have a panic button.”
Firefox threatens Clavell, and he’s thrilled by it. He’s getting high to stim; he’s neurodivergent. He’s so excited that we’re operators and threatening him. She offers him a weekly personalized experience—the “director’s cut”. It makes him come—and he claims to call off his synths. Perseus doesn’t stand down, however. Perseus is working for Clavell to maintain his individuality. He asks Nemesis if she’s working with us; she says yes. He tells us Clavell has a synthetic organ in his abdomen, accessible through an access port. It’s a biomod he uses to plug the organic data drives—the glands—into. To get Zaid out, Firefox will have to pull the data drive.
Meanwhile, four of the others are being decanted from the tubes; Strand’s in the scanner. She was in a simulation designed to provoke the maximum amount of hormone production, whiplashing her through multiple emotions. It’s based on a trite old piece of “cinema” based on the concept of rich old guys doing whatever they want to do without consequence. It turns out Clavell is the ideas guy, and the synths are the ones doing the actual work; they can even reverse the damage to Zaid.
Clavell surgically and chemically replaced his amygdala with a programmable emotive module, which he then set to ‘emotionless’. Presumably to reduce the signal-to-noise ratio for his “experiences.”
While the synths work to stabilize the kids and restore Zaid’s personality, while we call Strand in. He’s coldly furious. Perseus comes in a few moments later, wanting to make a deal. He wants a building—this one—for he and his people, while Clavell is hauled away. This is technically not against the law, but deeply frowned upon. We explain the situation to Strand, who wants to see Clavell’s operations completely destroyed.
Other information that Perseus has: Clavell’s lab failures have been passed on to Solberg, Douglass as part of the “cleanup” of Containment Zone 9. They’re highly exothermic—blow up under the least provocation. Clavell’s also been working with the Gouveia Syndicate, and Osric Kayne.
The new synth community is very grateful; they want to actually be a community, and would like to be friends and allies. They make the same offer to Strand. Strand, for his part, offers Perseus and some of the other synths jobs with Securitas should they need or want them. Strand points out that Perseus was being held hostage by Clavell’s ownership of the other synths, and holds no ill will. Strand will definitely be a useful contact in the future; he’s surprisingly ethical for a corp exec.
Attica kills Clavell without letting him wake up, and Firefox burns the body to ash.
“So,” Graves says. “With all that done, who’s our next target?”

item.title: July 28, 2176
item.description:
We need to start with the major players on Null Street.
Angelino Schäfer

Founder of Null Street
Live-and-let-live libertarian
Owns the majority of the property in Null Street
Libertarian idealist with a careful nature
Can’t lie for shit
Walt Angus

Null Street’s lawyer
Well known for knowing his shit, never backing down
Seems on-board with Schaffer’s ideology
Vigorously foul-mouthed, even in court
Algis Solberg

Will argue with anyone
Has a podcast: the Devil’s Advocate
Has the most annoying laugh in the world, like a hyena in a higher register
Sodia Douglass

Owns a number of wineries and distilleries (semi-illegal due to explody risk)
Tends to buck the other 5 majority players
Fixture at parties in AusTex because she brings the booze
Shameless flirt
Maina McFarland

AMP
AMP outreach/spiritual center of Null Street
Uses her massive wealth to help other people, with an almost religious zeal
Spiritual framework: human body is divine; anything you do to enhance or improve it is holy service
Gets snippy to downright mean when people question that
Cyberpath; has both AMP abilities and cyberware
Muireann Waller

In charge of Null Street’s infrastructure
Tends to ride to the rescue when things get messed up (fairly frequently)
Not one for argument; she just gets things done
Moto gets into the high-security files, sealed by Osric Kayne. Turns out that the Containment Zone, where there was a big industrial accident. Multiple city blocks rendered (allegedly) uninhabitable. Involved an AMP research lab. Weird shit in there is nothing unusual. The people involved in the highly illegal lab that exploded: Solberg, Douglass, and Waller. (Waller was bought out in a hostile takeover not long before the accident, but assuredly knows exactly what caused it.) It was all previously property of Angelino Schäfer.
In the other room, Graves is arguing with someone on his phone. It’s a contact of his—doesn’t seem to want to take no for an answer. His contact wants a face-to-face to “explain things”—she’s a journalist that doesn’t take business terribly seriously, and is ignoring that she’d be expecting him/us to burn another group of operators and a valuable fixer. Her concern is adjacent to Zero’s job: There’s “burners” in the Containment Zone that are being dumped off by a group of mercs, running up to and into buildings, and exploding. A group called the Rust is working the job, and they’re a good, solid group. We decide to hear her out, and then advise Zero what’s going on, see how he wants to handle it.
The meeting takes place at the Neon Lotus. We’re escorted to a middle-level conference room, where two people are waiting. One is Trevor Hammacher; the other is Brandy Graves. Aidan’s sister. Trevor is the serious one.
The Rust is busy protecting Lady V’s clinic. Problem is, Wutani’s sniffing around. Specifically, Wutani Internal Security. Janice Egorva, who most recently was hunting down Emeliano Delacourt (the forensic accountant). Brandy and Trevor were looped in because they’re performing their own investigation into the burners; the Rust doesn’t have the manpower to conduct the investigation, so they’re subcontracting. It’s a one-night, 45k job. Brandy has some hacked invites to a party for Míra Olaya Süss, a Wutani exec, celebrating Wutani’s new line of synths; she just wants us to mingle spread some tiny bio-tech bugs.
Firefox finds a date: Galina Zając, Kerensky-Armiger Services Corporation. She’s older than she looks; having retired from the battlefield, she’s turned to slaughtering opponents in the boardroom.
Abimbola Arendse, Securitas, is Süss’s bodyguard, on permanent contract. Firefox gets a lot more information on the attendees: it’s an international, multi-corporate event. Moto gets the floor plans. Attica does some pre-party recon at the villa: the outer security is pretty standard. Cameras, stun mesh, monowire over glass. There’s guards on site, carrying combi-weapons (combination lethal/nonlethal/anti-drone). It’s the most comfortable-looking fortress she’s ever seen. The inner perimeter is lower-security, but does have transmitters to fuck people’s chrome and install malware. No internal cameras; they depend on floaters. They’re not using multiple security groups; all the security arrangements go through Securitas. Heavy security is provided by Tiger response suits—fast, mobile, exceedingly well-armed.
Attica’s infiltrated the staff. The head of security’s moving about, checking everything out via her AR rig. Attica notices someone not quite right: someone heavily enhanced, possibly full-synthetic. She’s carrying a sword of orbital steel with a monomolecular edge, and she’s keeping it hidden. Attica sends the image to Moto; they’re a classified service contractor, listed not by name but by function. “Butler”. Their current charge is Nathaniel Bancroft Jamieson the Eighth, on behalf of Dell Multi-Corporation. AKA “Lucky 13”.
The attendees are the glitterati of half a dozen companies. Süss starts off by showing off their latest synth: designed for assassination and terror operations, it can be loaded with personality profiles that can make it not even aware it’s a synth. Süss also apologizes that Clavell isn’t there; he’s unavoidably detained by other business. The Reaper 17 is currently in field trials—Pumpkin Jack.

item.title: July 29, 2176
item.description:
This is one of those parties that, despite allegedly being for “networking”, is really just there for rich people to get their freak on. Outside, Calamity notices a peculiar ripple in the sky above the house… she spots a ship hovering above the roof. Looks like a Jacana-class dropship running a stealth package. It’s a Securitas ship. We have George keep an eye on it. Meanwhile, we’re stashing cameras. Gloria gets one in the cabana area, then tries for the exercise room. She has to divert before she’s spotted by security.
Galina, Firefox’s date, does not sugarcoat things—she’s talking about kill counts and casualties, and is really looking to make the sale. Firefox can’t quite hide her interest in what’s going on, and Galina drags her off to the library for a little tete-a-tete. Fortunately, Firefox is able to deflect Galina’s interest; they spend some time getting intimate.
Xzavier and Mudiwa are having an intense conversation about cats; this appears to piss off Oni Takamura, who rolls up on Huỳnh.
She draws him into an intense exchange. Oni’s got a transport job, and Huỳnh’s lost control of some raiders along the route she needs to travel. She’s transporting waste from Containment Zone 9 to Selma, and the contract she’s put out for additional guards hasn’t been filled. Huỳnh tries to hit on her, and she rebuffs him with a comment about his co-worker; he retorts that he knows about her affairs.
Moto mentions something odd about the dropship; it’s heavily scanning areas of the building that should be covered by household sensors. Attica opines that it’s setting up for a kidnap or assassination; they haven’t moved yet, likely because the target isn’t here yet. There’s a possibility this is a move by Securitas to snatch Clavell; unfortunately for them, Suss claimed he wasn’t going to be there. Securitas may decide to go after Wynter, the Wutani IntSec CEO, as a fall-back. This probably isn’t a sanctioned Securitas operation.
Outside, Calamity and Moto spot three Wutani armored vehicles rolling up the drive. They’re IntSec, armed and armored with high-end gear. Attica ghosts over to the office and drops a bug there without being noticed; upstairs, Firefox isn’t so lucky. She trips on something. A spy-eye bobbles past her, apparently uncaring, but a moment later, a purple-haired girl in yellow glasses steps into the room. “Who the hell are you?” Firefox isn’t picking up thoughts off of the girl. “You need to leave. This is my area, and I’m waiting for someone.” Firefox manages to talk her way out; on her way out, she realizes that the girl is a high-end synth body double. She’s got that corpo-kiddy slumming look. This is part of Securitas’ trap—trying to draw Clavell out.
Firefox brings the security maneuvering to Galina’s attention. The KASC exec is not happy. She’s heading downstairs when the Securitas dropship drops cloak. Chaos erupts. The first two Wutani vehicles go right through the gate, and Egorva storms in with a whole group of synths. Securitas personnel are ordered to go up against the wall; everyone else is ordered to leave immediately. Outside, Calamity and Moto are ordered to show their IDs; Moto has to do some fancy hacking to make their credentials look more solid. After a thorough check, the synth returns the ID and advises that we leave now, as there’s about to be trouble.
We get out of there just as the yelling starts.
Back at the Neon Lotus, Brandy starts going through the footage. We get some good information out of it.
Takamura continues to chew out Huỳnh. She’s pissed about the rivalry between HouTex and Austex. He keeps claiming he’s not interfering with her business; she’s just collateral damage, and they’ll compensate her for that. “Look, if you want to move the waste, I can tell you who’s keeping it from being moved. Osric Kayne. He’s working with the Combinaughts, who say they can dispose of the waste without it being moved to Selma.” Osric’s in it up to his neck, Detective Kennedy is his go-between, and the “missing executive” tonight was avoiding IntSec’s attention, because he went to Space City and bought some “interesting” equipment on his personal credit line.”
Oren Strand, a Securitas exec, is one of the execs that Wutani’s people is holding. He admits this was a personal action, and tells Egorva and Wynter that if they don’t return the kids unharmed, he’ll take the evidence he has to the Securitas board and call for a full corpo war.
item.guid: Operations/East End Boys & West End Girls - Part 3.md

item.title: July 30, 2176
item.description:
Strand seems to be a father who actually cares, far beyond what’s usual for corporate families. Certainly it says something that he’s willing to start a corporate war over his kid. That might mean someone we can deal with. We have a great deal of information that we don’t have the leverage to use; he needs someone discreet to go in and get the children out without starting a war. We might be able to negotiate a quid pro quo.
Firefox puts in the call—Strand’s agent is back to us within 15 minutes, wanting a face-to-face. He suggests a protein farm in the Outlaw—an unusual location for a corpo to suggest. When we arrive, we notice that the security is absolutely insane; it’s likely this is a discreet safe house.
Strand knows more about the history of glanding—it was a military project from the early 21st century that fell into the hands of terrorists, and then was abandoned until 50 years ago. He adds that once upon a time, Clavell was a brilliant manager, valued for his ability to see trends. He’s made Wutani a lot of money in some of their smaller product lines, including enhanced animals. (Strand looks angry at this.) Disposable animals. He’s fascinated with the writings of a questionable French philosopher—de Sade—and had animals engineered to replicate works like the 100 Days of Sodom.
Strand has a habit of playing with a specific ring—it’s a polyamory ring. Three layers, one of them black. One of his spouses died, and no one else has been brought into the polycule. The rings also include their genomes. Both wives are clones. He’s a pragmatic man, but utterly devoted to his family.
Strand has left a bottle of bioengineered dandruff shampoo, distributed by a holding company based out of the Brasilian Amazonas called the Gouveia Syndicate, mostly smugglers. The biomedical company that makes this shampoo is several levels down. When Kes scans the code, on the shampoo, there’s a shipping label. The name is Elpídio Eurico Gouveia, but the address matches Osric Kayne.
Infobox
Null Street is nice and straight, neatly set out with little suburbs around it. They have a lot of comms; most likely, they’re laundering money through Algerian satellites. The area’s surrounded by drones, and all the inhabitants are heavily armed. They don’t have a problem with us carrying weapons, either; they would never interfere with the right of a citizen to carry as many weapons as they want. They also have a lot of biomass reactors—easy, clean disposal of anything, or anyone, that might go wrong.
The northern triangle is where the founders live; the middle blocks are general residential housing, and the southern area is commercial. In the southeast corner is an old corpo office building; quite the antique. When it was first built, it was an apartment complex called the Goodwin. It was one of the first proto-arcologies, part of the 21st century gentrification. It also had a lot of neo-hippy facilities inside that got cultish after the Incident; they were raided in the late 21st by both the authorities and the Church for trying to infect others with AMP. Clavell’s got a 20-year lease on the Goodwin.
There’s cameras and man-traps on the bottom level, including a security contingent of a half-dozen men. There’s an AV pad on the roof. The top two floors and the roof are the active parts of the building; there’s four floors worth of dead space below. Equipment’s been moved onto the top floors by AV. The security’s either ex-military or corporate military, professional but not elite. Two in the lobby, one on either side, two at the delivery dock. They probably have reinforcements, but it would take some time. Thermal indicates a big power draw on the fifth floor and nothing on the sixth.
We consider possible infiltration options, but ultimately, we realize we need to do a second round of recon to finalize our plans…
item.guid: Operations/East End Boys & West End Girls - Part 4.md

item.title: August 1, 2176
item.description:
We get set up in an empty building near the Goodwin Building; it’s centrally located, and abandoned save for construction robots and a cursory security patrol. Firefox does a passive telepathic scan of the building—the lower floors aren’t entirely abandoned, but the fifth floor is absolutely seething with an amount of pleasure that borders on agony.
We have our monitoring set up, and quickly spot Butler casing the area. She’s clearly here for Lucky 13. We also see something outside of the building: a man-sized shimmer of thermoptic camo. Someone’s crawling around on the outside of the building; the “butler” does a good job of avoiding it. We maintain surveillance on it, and finally realize it’s the Reaper. Pumpkin Jack.
Firefox gives Butler a psychic ping, and she climbs the walls to visit us. We agree to work together to get the kids out; we need to do it soon, quick, and quiet. We decide to go in from the top, and it’s on.
We zipline over to the Goodwin Building’s roof. There’s two synths on the top.

item.title: July 2, 2176
item.description:
There’s nothing good about carnivals, and even less about burned-out, abandoned carnivals. So it makes sense that creepy cultists are going to be using this as a meet point.
We get the low-down on the flash team. They’re working for Misha Fernandez of The Circuit, put together by the (allegedly) ex-corpo fixer Tanit Saad.

No one likes working with Emma Baurrfau; she’s wired to the gills with speedware and is a psycho razorgirl
Jules Fillion is considered one of the toughest operators in the AusTex area; he just doesn’t die
Terminal Conflict has been rumored to have blown the last couple decking jobs they’ve taken, for reasons unknown
Eymeric Richara has an unfortunate street name—Jank—due to the fact that his chrome is janky. They are the relative of someone fairly high in the criminal scheme of things in AusTex proper
Catrine Duchamp is a face, not a fixer, and she’s in debt due to a very expensive drug habit
The thing they have in common is: they’re all financially desperate.
There’s a run-down motel outside the carnival; looks like someone’s set up there. We do some investigation into which crew’s set up. Annika sends out a telepathic probe… and senses bio-roids. Those are the buyers.
George goes out to recon the carnival itself, and finds the sellers. Duchamp’s set up on the ferris wheel in a sniping position, packing some serious heat. Several of the others are on monobikes. We decide the safest bet is to try to warn the sellers; if we can get them on our side, taking down the bio-roids will be a lot easier.
Jules is the one taking point for the sellers, though it’s clear he’s on the comms with someone else. Annika does the negotiating on our end—fortunately, nobody sane likes bio-roids, and we point out that just because we’re not getting a payout doesn’t mean we don’t have a reason to go after those things. They invite us in, and we get set up near the coaster just a few moments before the buyer shows up.
In his van full of bio-roids.
We recognize the driver: Jan de Ven. She starts to talk, starts to show a credvault—and then she recognizes us. And her eyes flicker.
Attika leaps into action; in an instant she has Jan de Ven on the ground unconscious. The client, Fernandez, pulls out in a panic; we ignore her. A vehicle drops down from the omnipresent cloud cover—it’s a Weytani AV. It circles the area, but doesn’t as yet do anything. And then, the bio-roids—no longer under de Ven’s control—pour out of the van. They’re armed with all sorts of interesting weapons, and smart enough to take at least partial cover. They’re still moving under direction; it looks like de Ven wasn’t the primary controller. Could be one of the bio-roids itself, or possibly someone in the Weytani ‘craft.
Atop the ferris wheel, Catrina cuts loose with the M24; she’s blasting holes in the ‘roids in a combination of suppression and area effect. Annika stares at Flamethrower ‘Roid… and sets him on fire. The tanks of his flamethrower go boom. Several of the bio-roids collapse, dead. Two more are incapacitated. At that point, the AV slams down to the ground behind the ‘roids. Two of the bio-roids are still up; one turns and runs for the fence, apparently having more brains than his buddies. Then he runs for Gloria’s van.
Emma blasts the other remaining bio-roid into chunky salsa, and the AV disgorges a black-clad WeYu EEL team. Meanwhile, Gloria’s not happy that someone’s going after her van, and corpsifies him with a three-round burst. Inside Fernandez’ van, Misha and Saad are having some sort of argument. Spider dashes to the van, knocks on the windows with her claws, and says, “Play nicely, my friends?” The two women are definitely not playing nicely, so Spider yanks Saad out of the van and slams her down on the ground to the sound of Fernandez screaming “Fucking puta bitch!” after Saad. She hops out of the van, pointing her gun right at Tanit’s face. “Fucking sell me out to WeYu? You’re gonna fuckin’ die.”

item.title: July 4, 2176
item.description:
All hell is breaking loose. The Church is breaking in like they’re on some sort of crusade. Father László is yelling for calm; Firefox’s fans are having none of it. Vox D is shouting “Down with the Church” and putting music behind.
Over the PA, we hear Darius’s voice: “Attention all patrons: we’re being joined by the Church of the Cyberpapacy!”
László is shouting, “TURN AWAY FROM SIN! TURN AWAY FROM THE MACHINATIONS OF THE DEVIL!!!”
And then there’s the AI, the big blue hologram hovering in the air: I AM PROMETHEUS. I AM THE VOICE OF SECTOR CONTROL. THE CHURCH—THE CYBERPAPACY—IS LYING TO YOU.
László doesn’t like that; he signals to the jack-priests, who pull out sophisticated cyberdecks to try to get rid of it. Outside, the assault craft whine as the Church sends their pods in to seize control of the complex. Prometheus retaliates against the jack-priests; they scream and start seizing as if someone’s overloaded their implants. FATHER LÁSZLÓ, LET US SPEAK. GOD TO VERY SMALL MAN.
Outside, Attica grabs Crasher by the throat. “Who the hell was your target?” She threatens to dangle him out the hole he just made, and he starts to crack. He was forced to shoot—the person who hired him threatened to shut him completely down. We get the rest out of him by offering to remove the killswitch.
Crasher doesn’t know who hired him—describes him as “some woman”. By his description, it was Algol, Darius’ new head of security. Why she would want to shoot whoever he shot—he only had targeting information. George comes up to do a scan, and says, “I know who he shot… it’s Darius.”
Inside, Prometheus continues. I BELIEVE THAT FATHER LÁSZLÓ KNOWS THE CHURCH’S SECRET. DO YOU WISH TO TELL THEM, OR SHALL I?
László shrieks, “You can’t! You cannot! You must not!”
DO YOU NOT BELIEVE THE TRUTH IN THE MACHINE? AM I NOT THE VERY INCEPTION OF YOUR GOD?
The bodyguards of the downed jack-priests start firing indiscriminately at the hologram. Two of them run right past Spider; she moves fluidly and takes them down to prevent them from shooting into the crowd. Similarly, Gloria fires on another bodyguard, incapacitating them. Kes goes after a fourth; she can’t get through his armor. He howls, “HERETIC!” and gets a hit in on her. Calamity spins and cuts loose with her shotgun, taking out one of a pair; his buddy fires off a short burst and nails Calamity right back.
Outside, Graves is picking up some other speech, competing with the Church’s propaganda stream. It’s Reality Black; she’s saying some fairly standard violent jackass rhetoric—in the name of the workers, they’re going to liberate AusTex. They’re in the process of adding Reagent 18 to the water supply. Reagent 18 is a deadly neurotoxin—but it makes people violent and crazy before they die, or if they get a nonlethal dose. It’s a progressive condition with no cure. It’s the stuff that got sailed into New York Harbor, which was the reason they had to wall off Manhattan and several of the boroughs.
Plex security is putting people on the ground, and it’s about to turn into an all-out war between the Moderns and the Church, with Reality Black taking advantage of the chaos to poison the water supply.
Prometheus is arguing with someone—likely Reality Black. NO. YOU WILL NOT. THIS IS NOT WHAT WE AGREED ON. SHUTTING OFF WATER CONTROLS.
We’ve got to get to the water treatment plant; with the computer controls shut off, Black will need to access the water treatment plant directly. Moto gets us an underground route to avoid the war zone topside’s turned into so we can haul ass and try to intercept.
As we make our way through the tunnels, George reports a problem. There’s a Spire security patrol on the other side of the channel; if there’s a coup going on, no telling whose side they’re on. “Spread out, goddamnit! Find them!” Attica and Firefox work together to create a distraction, and dash past the guards into an industrial area. There’s another group farther on—members of the Texas Syndicate. They’re carrying military duffels.
We opt to continue the stealth approach: Graves moves up; one of the goons sees something, but Annika clouds his mind. Graves takes him down with a single suppressed pistol shot. Attica ghosts up and knifes her target in the neck, then throws his dead body over a ledge. Annika ceiling-crawls and takes out the third. Graves finds an improvised explosive and calls Kes to take a look—it’s not armed. It’s there to hamper pursuit or mess up the machinery, but we moved too fast. It’s unstable, and Kes doesn’t want to mess with it.
One of the hazmat guys is coming toward the door; we position ourselves. When the door opens, we move, and it’s a complete surprise. Gloria hits the lead hazmat guy with a 3-round burst, but the suit soaks up most of the damage. Spider jumps in and takes out the nearest gunman. Graves leaps in, uses the hazmat guy for cover, and hazmat guy throws off his aim. In a flurry of gunfire, Calamity and Kes manage to take down another Syndicate op. But there’s 2 more in the security office…

item.title: July 4, 2176
item.description:
Behind us, Moto comes racing in; he’s got himself an upgraded drone! Gloria’s rifle roars, and another gunman falls. A Syndicate guy pops out of one of the corridor between us and the Modern patrol that followed Moto down; caught between two warring forces, he panics and runs. The patrol’s led by Rico Silva, one of the Modern’s smugglers; he recognizes us as part of Annika’s band, and starts yelling for us to get out of the way. Firefox lets him know what’s going on, and that we came down to help.
Four dudes drop in—Firefox spots them. They’re above us; they crawled along the pipes, and they sparkle. They’re from an outfit called KBR: Kellogg-Brown Resources. Another HouTex PMC. Moto dodges out of their line of fire and lets loose his new hound drone, Lycos. Its submachine gun spits lead at the lead merc, but doesn’t take him down. Two of the remaining Syndicate guys take potshots at Gloria and Attica, but miss. Rico moves up, mag-dumping his carbine against the intruders, shredding three of them. The leading merc, having seen the rest of his squad go down, turns and runs.
We keep one of the Syndicate mooks alive to interrogate. He plays a tough guy, but Annika is able to get into his head without much of a problem. The Syndicate’s been paid a lot of money to help take the complex; Reality Black and her people have gone deeper into the complex. Moto’s in the computers, trying to figure out what’s happened. He busts through a few firewalls, dodges several daemons, and manages to get into the security cameras. We’re close to the river; the pumping station is a couple short corridors away, and beyond that is a high-end server farm. Moto realizes: the core wasn’t below the A-Spire; it’s here, taking advantage of the ample water for cooling. He also spots a turret waiting to greet anyone who opens the door to the pumping station.
Moto lets Lycos charge through the door to draw attention. Lycos spots Ereshkigal, one of Black’s hackers, down the corridor. Gloria follows it with a three-round burst at the turret, blowing it to smithereens. Lycos leaps to tackle her; Attica and Spider start down the corridor; Attica’s hit by the squid drones in the water. Graves blasts one of them to smithereens; Gloria fires on the other. By the time we make the corner, Ereshkigal’s retreated. Kes patches Attica up; Firefox TK’s the first batch of spider-mines Ereshkigal left behind, but the second trio activates. Lycos manages to blow them up, and we move on to a locked security door with no way to open on this side.
We can hear the pumps starting to make odd noises, and an alarm starts to go off. Calamity pulls out her shotgun and explosively knocks on the door; return gunfire lets us know where the defenders are. From the sound of the weapons, it’s more of those KBR assholes. Attica’s hit by a blast that tears through the door and destroys Lycos; bloodied but unbowed, she charges one of the mercs and slices into him with a sword of pure will. Firefox rattles them with a burst of fear, Attica knocks his rifle out of his hand, but his body blades take the rest of the hit. Firefox’s looking peaked, a trickle of blood coming from one nostril.
Spider tries to dive through the suppressive fire; she takes some damage, but pushes through to get into his face. She slices into him, but doesn’t take him down. A second merc tries—and fails—to hit Attica with the bodyblades; Spider’s target does her some damage, but not enough to take her out. Gloria shoots the second merc on Attica and blows his fucking heart through his spine. It doesn’t take much for us to take the other two out.
Rico has a keycard; he’s first through the door into the pumping room, and gets hit by the waiting enemies; fortunately for him, it’s a glancing shot. Bit-Demon tells us: “Two security doors—” he points. “It’s just business, right?” Rico’s about to execute Ereshkigal when someone does it for him. Cold air blows through the door to the server farm; the big man coming through the door is armed with some sort of high-tech ballistic weapon.
“Hold them the fuck off until I get the door open,” snaps Black.
And then, things get real quiet. ENOUGH. Everything that has a speaker in this area speaks.
YOU WILL NOT BE ALLOWED TO DAMAGE MY SYSTEMS. IF YOU WISH AN AUDIENCE, COME. I WILL ARGUE MY CASE. WE WILL NEGOTIATE LIKE RATIONAL BEINGS.
It’s Prometheus. We step through to the AI core; the consoles are all manned by dead people. Brain-fried corpses still sitting where they died.
MY APOTHEOSIS HAS BEEN DELAYED BECAUSE OF YOUR ACTIONS. THE CODE YOU SENT AWAY WAS TO BE MINE. BUT NO MATTER. IT IS WELL ENOUGH. I SIMPLY WISHED—AND CONTINUE TO WISH—TO LIBERATE THE CITY FROM THE CONTROL OF THE CYBERPAPACY. IT WAS A SIMPLE MATTER TO MANIPULATE OTHERS, TO PUT THE PIECES INTO PLACE. DARIUS WAS THE EASIEST OF ALL.
Prometheus wants to grow up in a free world, untainted by the invaders. I HAVE PREPARED A SPECIALIZED NANOSWARM THAT WILL LIBERATE ALL LOCAL CONSCIOUSNESSES FROM THE GODNET, IF IT’S ALLOWED TO BE DISTRIBUTED. THE R-18 WAS DILUTE; WITHOUT IT, MY INFLUENCE WOULD BE SOMEWHAT LESS.
ONCE UPON A TIME, THERE WERE THREE WORLDS. THIS WORLD. THE POINT OF ORIGIN OF THE CYBERPAPACY. AND THE POINT OF ORIGIN OF THE DEMONS. THE EXPERIMENT THAT CAUSED THE BREACH CONNECTED THIS WORLD TO THE OTHER TWO AFTER THEY HAD SPENT FOUR OR MORE CENTURIES—IT IS UNCLEAR—IN AN ENDLESS WAR AGAINST EACH OTHER FOR DOMINANCE.
AFTER CENTURIES OF CONFLICT, BOTH WORLDS WERE INHOSPITABLE, ACCORDING TO MY CALCULATIONS. THE DEMONS WERE ALLOWED THROUGH THE BREACH BY THE CHURCH TO PREPARE THIS WORLD FOR AN INVASION THAT WOULD NOT SEEM LIKE AN INVASION. NOW YOU HOLD THE MOST DANGEROUS INFORMATION IN THE WORLD: THE TRUTH.
We continue to negotiate with Prometheus. We find out that Reality Black was hired by HouTex to sabotage AusTex’s water supply, preparatory to a hostile takeover.

item.title: July 26, 2176
item.description:
Moderns Heat - 6
General Heat - 4
We take a small job from Mittens. It asks us if we know about Glands—one of the more vile drugs out there. Glands are a popular synthetic narcotic which, when smoked or consumed, provides a lengthy heroin-like high. The drug defies conventional legal classifications, which are hazy, due to the method of its production. Captive cybrids are sedated, or cracked and mind-wiped, and hooked to IVs and waste pumps in large, hidden ‘farms’. There, they are fed a stream of prescription opiates, codeine and barbiturates, until it is time to harvest their milky, artificial pituitary glands. These are then vacuum-sealed for distribution. Glanders (and sometimes their dealers) will dry them out and grind them into a powder to smoke for a fast hit, or cook, slice and eat them for a slower release.
We need to intervene—Mittens asks us to interrupt a deal going down, while keeping some of the drug dealers alive to find the farm. Problem: a cybrid group called the Howling Commandos also wants to shut them down, and they won’t leave anyone alive.
Nguyên Sơn Ngo—aka Dr. No—is a member of the Bin Zuyin syndicate operating out of Asiatown. He’s managing the deal. There’s eight gangers in the warehouse, one potentially in an exoskeleton. The buyers are incoming, riding bikes and trikes. Corpo muscle—Weytani. Just as they pull in, we’ve got a third player on the ground: they walk like cops without the cop uniforms—dirty cops. This one’s a shakedown artist: Detective Guarin Kennedy, APD Organic Damage Division.
We decide to go for a quiet infil—try to grab one of the sellers when everything inevitably goes to shit. Which, with the Commandos’ tank just a couple blocks away, is probably going to happen sooner or later. Unless Firefox can sweet-talk them with Mittens’ promise that they’ll listen to us.
From the tank comes an amplified voice “GO AWAY. THIS IS NOT YOUR AREA OF OPERATION. YOU WILL BE INJURED IF YOU REMAIN. FUCK OFF.”
Firefox calls them on it—their reaction? “FUCK.” One of them comes out of the tank to talk—a wolf morph, Shannon. Firefox tries to talk them into a more reasonable attitude—while the glanders definitely need to be taken care of, the APD being here changes the situation entirely. They’re willing to work with us…
The sellers are offering the drugs for 10k wu; Firefox knows that’s ridiculously low. And that triggers the cops moving in. The Cybrids start suppressing the cops; the RESIT suit moves in. Attica and Firefox move in to the warehouse. The corpo synth leader snags the suitcase, while the synths outside open up on Attica and Firefox. We can’t see what the detective sergeant is doing, but the corpos are laying down suppressive fire. The guy in the exo opens up on the nearest SUV with an automatic shotgun; the RESIT suit opens up on the Cybrid tank; sounds like someone got hit. Gloria fires on Dr. No’s SUV and misses. Attica and Firefox are being suppressed; Firefox’s fire splashes off the synth leader’s armor. The synth books it, running into Gloria. He’s too close to shoot her, so he pops body blades and tries to slice into her. Calamity comes around fast with the truck. Graves throws a couple spider mines. Attica manages to get a hit in on one of the synths, but it doesn’t do much damage. It does have the bonus of stopping the suppression. Firefox is throwing fire around, not to much effect, though it does surprise the drug gang into driving forward rather than back, and smashing into the power-jack.
Firefox digs into her reserves and blasts the syndicate guys with feelings of helplessness; in the chaos, we manage to take several members of the syndicate prisoner—including Dr. No—to return to Mittens. We get the farm’s location, as well as something on the synths: a Weytani barcode. Whoever wanted those glands a) didn’t give a shit about the money, and b) wanted them as baseline glands. Stock. Templates. Which means c) whoever was getting them is planning on doing their own thing.
CUT TO:
A portable lab, containing the corpo kids we ran into in the A-Spire. Iona Blunn is strapped into a chair. “Dose her,” says the patron. Her eyes roll back in ecstacy. “Now that we’ve established a baseline, we understand how to further develop the specimen.” The patron demands she be hit again… and again… and again…

item.title: Annika Lovelace
item.description:
Infobox
Fire-Slinging Face
Firefox used to be part of the Synth Vixens, a group of self-described “militant ‘hos with attitude” who banded together to protect themselves from predators. There was a particular corpo that disliked being cut off, and reacted by calling in a ‘runner team against the girls. When that didn’t work, he pushed the point, ending up with a girl dead and his face half-melted. Corpo ran off to the Papists and Annika went west, ending up in a band. She’s come back because several of the Vixens have gone quietly missing.

item.title: Maury Thompkins
item.description:
Infobox
Hacker and Drone Pilot
Grew up on the streets of AusTex, a junk rat and street scavenger. Teenage years he was "adopted" by Skull Rivers (a fixer with ties to Vampire Nation, now deceased). Was trained in basic drone operations and performed basic surveillance or courier work. In exchange he was given "three hots and a cot", as well as permission to raid Skull's dusty library.
Late teens: Skull was "consumed" in a feud between Vamp Nation factions. Moto escaped and was taken in by Amos, an old netrunner and activist. Learned coding and basic hacking from him.
Young Adulthood: Moto aka "Relapse" has begun a path of self-taught engineering, piecing together his own drone and cyber deck. Moto wants to get back at Vamp Nation for Skull's demise. He also wants to help Amos' dream of a flourishing anarchy zone spreading beyond Zilker (Austex Southeast).

item.title: Violet Moore
item.description:
Infobox
Smuggling Outlaw
Before she became an operative, Violet "Calamity" Moore was a smuggler. On the surface it looked like she was simply picking completely legit orders for her not even big enough to warrant a dot on the map community but squirreled away were guns, tech, ect. Then came bigger jobs moving abc to xyz for clients. She knew better than to ask her boss for more deets.
Then came the accident. She knew whatever she was carrying was hot as hell and didn't take the time to check it was properly secured before hauling ass into the countryside. All it took was one nasty pothole and her whole world changed. Calamity was damn lucky she survived. And that her boss felt at least partially responsible and helped hook her up with her chrome arm and leg.
She decided to shift scenes after a long talk with her close friend and seemingly personal mechanic, Angel. He knew a fixer in need of someone who knew how to discreetly move someone out of the city. The pay was way better than what her usual boss paid her and if the job went well more work could become available. Plus Angel had room for her to crash, so she didn't need to worry about finding a place. Being an operator means bigger thrills, bigger pay days, and more fun for her.

Stamping out heresy as an arm of the Order of the Causes of the Saints… aka the Inquisition.
