item.title: March 13, 2176
item.description:
The leader of the Panzer Hammers has been killed by the Vampire Nation. There’s a lot of infighting as the gang tries to decide who the new leader’s going to be. This is causing general unrest.
We’re all hanging out at the local Tombs dive bar, the Knife Shop. There’s a few jobs going around; we end up picking one up from Henry Jericho, one of the local fixers.
The client is Oliver Gaskell. He’s an ex-con who has a contact who desperately needs to get out of the AusTex area. The principal is holed up in the old ReFood in Sector N7. (We’ve eaten there, and lived to regret it.) The job is simple, get him out and to the RV point. The complicated part is that he’s under siege from corporate agents and they have heavy drone coverage. Another complication is that ATR has a copshop nearby, in sector N9.
Our contact, Mittens, wants to meet us at the Grand Metropol Hotel. The Presidential Suite. The elevator smells of burning insulation and industrial lubricants; the cybrids here are not well-maintained, and they have a tendency to glitch. It’s not a pleasant situation for any involved. The cybrids on duty watch us with dull yet enhanced eyes.
“Need human man. Human man know where my human man is. My human man is late. Need scritch. St!nkman after other man. Jericho say other man (Gaskell) in Refood. Other man supposed to—did not—help human—my human. I lab assistant. Very good assistant. Is work on silly thing, but important for hoo-man.” She lets out an exasperated sigh. “Very important for hoo-man.”
“St!nkman come to door; Mittens take picture. St!nkman now flat.” St!nkman is a freelance agent named Lloyd Ashworth. Crazy Lloyd. Lloyd’s the agent on the ground looking for the principal. He’s currently sitting in an armored sedan, probably on loan from whatever corp he’s working for. The sedan has a drone bay, entirely empty—looks like it could hold four drones. Lloyd looks pissed. He looks as if he’s trying to figure out exactly what stupid thing he’s about to do…


Lloyd looks like he’s about to blow his top, so we need to move fast. Spider and Kes go in the front, Attica goes in the back, and Moto and Calamity are in the truck. One of Lloyd’s drones investigates them; they play dumb, lost civvies. A second drone spots Attica in the back; she manages to lose it by going inside the back door. Abruptly, two of Lloyd’s drones start acting odd; zooming off in various directions, giving us an opportunity.
While the rest of the team is getting Oliver Gaskell out, Attica saunters over to Lloyd’s car—turns out he’s being blackmailed by the corp, and isn’t real thrilled about being forced to work for whoever it is. Scuttlebutt has it that Lloyd is working for the corps, a job gone wrong. He tried to lean on Earl for something—whatever it was, the corps felt it was worth an international incident—but it wasn’t violent. Meanwhile, we’re getting Oliver out to where there’s supposed to be a hidden car near the Aerospace port. We get him there, and he says he owes us one. And just as a bit of advice, he says to avoid Koizumi Aerospace Corporation—whatever it is they want to buy, it’s hot. The talent they had earlier were high-velocity, possibly even Synths.

item.title: March 14, 2176
item.description:
We got this job from Zero Ballard, who goes to the lengths of telling us that he neither likes nor trusts the client. The client wants a full investigation on one Dr. Narindar Nwolko. There’s a second job out there for a hit on a corporate exec that Nwolko did work for, so we’re going to have to play this one careful. The client’s interested in anything Dr. Nwolko might be doing that’s outside his usual routine or expertise.
We’ve got a couple leads; we can look at the guy who’s taken the job to hit the ‘zek, we can head out to Techtown and see what we can find. Moto does some investigation into Nwolko. Meanwhile, Attica makes a call—she knows one of Nwolko’s clients, Aidan Graves.
Aidan knows a lot more:
Nwolko installed reactive armor into one of the Panzer Hammers; turns out the installation didn’t take. Which got the boss of the Panzers perma-killed. This threw all sorts of things into chaos, like plans to go after the Spirit Moderns. The Spirit Moderns stole something high-powered from WET; the Panzers were supposed to be muscle for the attempt to take it back. Apparently the Panzers were getting a little above themselves, and the ‘failed installation’ might have been deliberate, creating a change in leadership. Now, the Panzers are toeing the line of their corpo masters, and getting paid in trade. And while that fight went down, the Vampire Nation got off the shot that killed the Hammers’ bossman.
In short, it’s a real mess.

For the immediate job, Graves can get us into TechTown without being scanned too heavily. We pull up to Nwolko’s clinic, and they’re in somewhat of a panic. That high-velocity talent from the other day, muscle from Koizumi (that may or may not be synths), is leaning on the clinic staff. Nwolko has that professional stone-face going on, though.
Graves is keeping Nwolko occupied, while Gloria and I look around. Moto’s looking through Graves’ eyes; one thing that the doctor did not do was close his files. There’s a couple dossiers: the one on the left is Zina Kova, high-powered horizontal talent for the Spirit Moderns. She’s been acting as the roper for Alistair /name/, who wants the contract for Artemis Sonata. (Who wanted us to get her special friend free from the Moderns.) The second photo is one Terra McAllister—former employee of WET. Her employment was terminated just a few days ago.
Those in the van spot some incoming heat: Verner Jackstadt; Jericho did mention that a ‘big-ass cyborg’ had called the hit job on Nwolko’s client. He leaves behind a guy in a souped-up hovercar: Daron Ocano. Kes and Spider head over to the car to see if they can exploit Ocano’s addiction to leave Jackstadt high and dry.
Meanwhile, the Koizumi guys take cover, and Nwolko politely tells Graves that they’ll need to follow up later; Graves directs us to the side door. Meanwhile, Ocano takes the bait and wanders to the van. Moto looks scruffy enough to be a dealer; when he hands Ocano a chip, Ocano just slots it and gets glitched out of his goddamned mind. Moto grins and heads over to Ocano’s float car, sliding behind the wheel…
Verner turns, slowly; sees Moto there, narrows his eyes and stalks toward the car. Moto waves cheerily and throws the car into reverse… unfortunately, Verner has nerveware. He’s fast. And he spins up his weapons…
Automated turrets spin up, blaring an alarm. WARNING! WARNING! THIS IS A SECURED AREA! LAY DOWN YOUR WEAPONS, SECURE YOUR CYBERWARE, AND DROP TO THE GROUND!
Verner’s so armored up that he ignores the first spray of light rounds, intended to tear through unprotected flesh. Something pops out of his forearm: he has a built-in combat shotgun that fires mini-grenades, and with a few shots those turrets disintegrate. His other arm pops open to reveal a razored pincer; he sprints forward with inhuman speed as the car starts to float out of his immediate reach! The Koizumi muscle scatters around to take cover, unlimbering combat rifles. Attica can’t hear anything from them; they must have internal comms. While the rest of us pile into Gloria’s van, she pulls out her own combat rifle and fires. It doesn’t do much more than sting him, but it’s enough to make him even angrier. He looks at the Koizumi guys, looks at us… and freezes. Gloria sends a three-round burst toward him, but misses; Graves pops off and manages to smash one of Verner’s optics. At that point, Verner starts running.
Everyone’s focused on Verner, nobody’s focused on us, and we get the hell out of there.


Reviewing what we got from the doctor’s office, things are about to get interesting. Both McAllister and Zina paid the doctor for various modifications, but the doctor fucked up. McAllister was supposed to get the courier drive carrying data; instead, she got a blank. Zina got the drive—but she doesn’t know she has it. Worse, the doctor managed to partially decrypt the data on the drive. It’s high-level stuff: a predictive algorithm based on certain astronomical characteristics. Specifically, the ability to predict destinations of wormholes, but it could also predict troop movements, crowd behavior, weather… it’s not a perfect Oracle, but anyone who has this thing would have one hell of an advantage over anyone who doesn’t.
Seems like someone at Koizumi got wind of the algo, hired the Panzers to take it from the Moderns, but the Panzers got ambushed and sidetracked when their top veck got perished. McAllister is the original thief, wanted the blackjack doc to install a courier drive...but somewhere in the mess, Zina got the courier drive with the white hot data installed and McAllister got a blank. Now the blackjack is sweating it because whoever wants the data is leaning on him to cough up who the thief was so they can track them down.
Problem is, McAllister doesn't have the data; Zina does, but doesn't know it. Zina's clearly planning to run away with Artemis in the name of True Love...but the Moderns want Artemis on a puppet string using Zina as a honey trap. Except that Zina's off the leash, which probably means the Moderns are hunting around for her...and the advantage they might get (assuming they could crack the drive somehow) would catapult the gang into megacorp status at least.
This will make absolutely no one happy.
How the Moderns got it, who the fuck knows? It's a bazoomy mess with not just a lot of deng involved, but power, the finest drug there is.

item.title: March 16, 2176
item.description:
We give an edited version of the information we found to Zero. He says to keep ourselves available; the client is likely to want more. We advise him he may want to decline from his end, as it’s getting ugly. We do get the payout, plus the location of a stash.
The stash is in Dome Town, at Violator. It’s the size of a full-size modular shipping container. There’s a cash vault—the number on it is 14.4K, some collectibles, a couple crates of current-gen Colonial-issue MREs (better rats than a lot of people eat right now). Below the container is a highly-shielded secondary container that’s set up as a small safe-house. It’s exceedingly small, because part of that safe-house includes a clone tank.
There’s also a single-use storage device: on it is a dossier. Combining the information in the dossier with the existence of both the algo and the clone tank suggests that Zheng was intending to create a flesh computer, a super-processor with an organic substrate.
We’re united in needing to destroy the algorithm. The easiest way is to simply kill Zina, but that’s a little distasteful. But Artemis Sonata’s job gives us an in. Rescue Zina from the Moderns.
We meet Artemis before her protest concert in front of the SleepDealers. Zina’s going to be at the show; Artemis is worried about that, because she thinks it means the Spirit Moderns are up to something. Zina says she was supposed to act as a middleman, hand off incriminating information to some guy named Ocano. That’s probably why the brainware was installed—Artemis thinks it’s a brainlock.
Artemis has a second request: she’s worried about the Panzers rolling up, but they’re too busy with their own leadership struggle. If anyone’s gonna roll up on the show, it’ll be the Moderns. Vampire Nation, possibly, just because they love music, but the Moderns might well try to crash the party and give her an offer she can’t refuse.
We agree to help with security. Attica and Graves walk the site, while Moto goes and gets himself a new off-the-shelf drone. The problem is… someone managed to stuff an AI in there. Named George.
George, it turns out, is a combat veteran, an expert system that became self-aware after a virus in the Somali War. It’s willing to do its part, and is extremely offended at Moto’s suggestion that he might flee.
Spider gets in touch with an old contact in the Moderns, and found out that her old boss, Delia Graydon, is going to be there.
The concert site’s a nightmare; it’s technically outdoor, but surrounded by urban blight. There’s too many ways someone could take a shot at Artemis, but we’ll do our best. The Moderns have set up cameras around the whole place, and they’re probably intending to create bootlegs. The data feed is going to Southby; there’s an indie studio called Skinjob Records just around the corner that the Moderns are clearly trying to undermine.
Zina’s here, escorted by Wynston Lien, watching from one of the rooftops; on another rooftop are members of the Vampire Nation. Not just any members, either: the Prince of the Vampire Nation herself, Nastasia Gwinelle and her retinue. This could spell trouble…
And does. Wynston’s on some narcosoft, and aggressive with it. One of the Vamps starts some trouble—he’s got Presence and Dominate mods installed, trying to back Wynston down. He’s not going to back down, though Zina freezes in panic. Attica hops over to the Prince’s balcony and manages to negotiate them into peace; unfortunately, Wynston decides to throw his weight around and Zina laughs at him. He shoves her back into the crowd of Moderns behind him and tells them to ‘have some fun’. Attica and Spyder move to intervene; George also moves in, but follows Wynston when he gets the call that we’ve interrupted their bootleg stream.
Gloria finally manages to dial in Delia; she’s on the balcony between the Moderns and the Vamps. And as the first Modern lays an unwelcome hand on Zina… shit gets real. Gloria blows a hole in the mob by blowing a hole through a Modern ganger. Attica uses the hole to pull Zina out of the crowd of her assailants, dropping down between two of the buildings to keep her out of Delia’s line of fire, as well. George ‘accidentally’ hits Wynston in the head, knocking him off the balcony in an unconscious heap. The SleepDealer guards run to his aid. Spyder decides to have some fun, gutting a second Modern.
Delia drops down, whispers “Spoiler!” and throws a grenade, and it’s placed too perfectly, and Attica’s just that instant too slow to protect Zina from it; Attica’s mildly injured, but Zina’s badly hurt. At that point, Delia leaps back up to the balcony to try to run. Gloria sights in at Delia; the bullet vaporizes her left leg. She collapses, and before the other Moderns can come to her aid, the Vamps dart in and drag her off.
We get Zina extracted to the van so Kes can start first aid; Gloria sends an address to Calamity and puts the lead on for the frantic run down to her hideout. It’s a rough road, but Kes is able to keep Zina alive just long enough to get her to the surgery. For just a moment, she flatlines… but Kes is finally able to stem the bleeding and stabilize her.
She’s not going to be stable for any kind of surgery for at least a month... but the drive is intact.
Artemis says, “I never thought the Moderns would go so far. It wasn’t your fault—who’d have thought she’d throw a grenade?”
The news comes on; the Spirit Moderns are being blamed for setting off a bomb at the concert. AusTex Response rolled in just after we bugged out.
In addition to the 30k in straight Wu, we get an additional 30k of street drugs, maker tools, and corpo industrial secrets—including a dossier.

item.title: July 2, 2176
item.description:
Even though we’ve been taking a couple months of quiet to let some of the heat die down, word is out on the street about what we can do. We’ve gotten some interest from a couple new fixers, while Henry Jericho (and his family) have gone completely off the grid.
One of those fixers, Cadence Flux, requests to meet with Annika specifically; she specializes in entertainment.
One of Flux’s friends, Reality Black, needs some overwatch. She’s got a problem with someone nobody likes—Darius Vasser, leader of the Spirit Moderns. Reality is getting together a crew of hackers to give him a really big black eye after he lost a couple of his people. Delia Graydon’s in the hands of the Vampire Nation, and Wynston Lien’s dead at the hand of the Panzer Hammers. Black is planning a run on the Plex, the heart of the Spirit Modern’s operations.
Black intends to infiltrate the Plex, evade, convince, or disable the Eye of Algol (aka the Demon, a noted hacker), fiddle with the water quality sensors, and exfiltrate.
We start initial planning, with the thought of sneaking in under cover of an interview with the latest shining star of entertainment. We just need to create said shining star…

Checking in with Earl at the Knife Shop, he’s got a private job, only for us. It’s delicate, and it doesn’t pay much. Someone’s gone in and cleaned out a bunch of the local favelas, and Social Services is looking into it. Some of the few survivors have reported that the Cyberpapacy has been seen in the area. The client is Abel Kane, a volunteer with Social Services, who wants to find out what’s happening. Earl apologizes; the job doesn’t pay much, but we take it regardless. The pay’s 25k, and Earl keeps trying to find ways to offer more, but we’re going to take this one as a goodwill job.
Zero’s heard some rumors. The Church down south is very interested in converting one of the Spirit Moderns, with the goal of sneaking psychopharmaceuticals into the water supply. The Cyberpriest in question is getting ready to go on one of their moral crusades: Bishop Silvestr Devin. If we play things right, we can embarrass him into pulling back. Our contact is a woman by the name of Simone Church. The payout’s 30k, plus whatever we come across.

The Erinye is set up in the Grand Metropol Hotel, on the 28th floor. She doesn’t appear to be a fan of the male sex or gender, but she doesn’t make a huge deal about it. Someone’s causing problems for one of her sisters on The Circuit; they need someone who’s deniable to deal with the problem. Her sister has an agent for munitions, and she thinks it’s a screw job; the deal is five days from now, so we need to find out what’s hinky before it goes down. The Erinye is offering this as an audition, but the pay is still good due to the unknowns. We’re requested to investigate using whatever means we see fit; if possible, report back for a final decision on how to proceed, but if we have to shut the deal down for a good reason, we have that authorization. The payout is 60k plus salvage, with the caveat that if the property is something owed to the sister in question, we do not have right of salvage. Unfortunately, we’re overbooked as it is, so we have to politely turn it down.

item.title: July 3, 2176
item.description:
We decide to start with the disappearances. The contact, Abel Kane, is out by the Veravas - Cradle Biolabs Agristacks, and that’s Panzer Hammers territory. We’re walking carefully; don’t want to bring trouble down.
Kane’s a combat vet; he and Gloria bond over shared combat traumas. Kane would ordinarily handle something like this himself, but this is different. Kane tells us it’s not the Papacy—they’re dropping in heavy-duty aerodynes, drones, the works. Ordinarily they aren’t so obvious; there’s a few missionaries in the district, but they tend to keep a low profile.
Infobox
Bio-roids
Abel got a look at the attackers via a low-res camera: they appear to be bio-roids of some sort, low-chrome, with an odd symbol on their heads. 3D-printed androids, made from organic slurry. They’re mass-printed without a full brain, though some can have an organic brain with cyberimplants. And cybereyes. They were (and in some places, are) used offworld for cheap labor; more typically, they’re used as cannon fodder. They have no sense of self-preservation outside the mission. In this case, the mission is clearing out the favelas and kidnapping people. Even worse, they have stunted immune systems; if there’s a disease around, they’ll catch it and become super-spreaders.
The process of printing off these things is simple: you need a small amount of nanites and sufficient amounts of biomaterial. We could do it with our clone tanks. The bottlenecks are biomass and the creation of a template.
Attica is utterly certain that these aren’t Cyberpapacy troops—this completely goes against the Cyberpapacy’s beliefs. These are an abomination of the flesh—men playing God.
The advantages: they can be cranked out by the job lot once you have the template; they can’t be hacked; they’re inexpensive, and they are utterly loyal.
There’s one gang in the area that might know something about the tech needed to create these things: the Vampire Nation. We contact Tallisi to set up a meeting; it won’t be until later in the evening.

A capsule hotel turned into a retirement home. Everything one expects of such a place. A lot of people crammed into too small a space, but a lot of them are old-school punks and highly unlikely to do something like narc.
Simone Church is in the basement; allegedly, this is where the cheap coffins are. We walk through a line of fake coffins and come into a secure, discreet meeting room. Her first words are: “Why the fuck is she here?” — referring to Attica. Attica knows her—they used to be cloistered sisters in the same convent. Church was part of the Order of St. Paul (the Caduceus), while Attica was in the Hospitallers. Attica explains that she got out—eighteen months ago.
The church has decided they’re going to co-opt the Modern’s sysadmin. They figure with two of the Moderns’ people down, now’s the time to move in. They’ve got a small force elsewhere in the Tombs, looking into something. They’re led by Sistrix Radoslava Barsamian, an investigator with the Order of St. Michael.
The Church experimented with bio-roids once; it went so epically wrong that an entire order of the church was destroyed, root and branch. Hospitaller-Captain Zimmerman is another fanatic—and another gifted such as Attica. He was part of the pogrom. Attica wonders if some member of the order may have escaped the pogroms. Simone hopes not—the head of the order was beyond heretical, going into insane.


Meeting with the Vampire Nation. The club is less crowded than usual, but the music is loud and the dancers are happy. The Prince is at the back; white sound generators are placed at strategic intervals to interfere with enhanced hearing. It’s probably not real blood that showers from the ceiling.
Prince Nastasia Gwinelle is waiting for us—she has already ensured our privacy, and invites us back into a secured room. Firefox outlines the situation with the bio-roids, and respectfully inquires into what the Nation might have heard regarding sites that might be suitable for setting up a bio-roid factory. The Prince summons someone to bring the information to us: Dog Girl. What comes walking out the back used to be human…

item.title: July 3, 2176
item.description:
Nastasia is probing for reactions to the abomination they’ve created of Delia Graydon, and by and large we don’t give her one. The information she gives us is on DNA-coded protein drives—very on point, even if she didn’t get a whole bunch of them remaindered. There’s several locations in the area of the disappearances that might be of interest…


The area we’re looking in is not the greatest. We go in as a group, we go in quiet, we go in defended and armed. We decide to leave the Tastygae algae processor and the couple pieces of hustle muscle lazing around it for last.
First stop is Dr. Skin. Dog Girl is probably a Dr. Skin product; he does a lot of biotech and cosmetic. Even Skin’s security is creepy; the turrets are made of muscle and shoot teeth at people, but they still do the job. Skin denies knowing anything about the bio-roids—they’re actually insulted at the thought. The synths are far too mundane for what they create. We agree to trade some wu for information. Outside, Moto’s running drone overwatch in the van, and spots a couple gangoons meandering around. They leave Moto and the van alone, so most likely working for Skin.
The Gen-1 bioroids were fairly simple, and were probably recycled to provide raw material for the next generation. The second generation had integrated armor, communications, and were fitted with nasty lobster claws, excellent for ripping through flesh and metal. Many are fitted with a common labor exoskeleton, but the 'roid in the second-gen pic is wearing a set of Hospitaller armor. That’s not the sort of thing that gets around—and it’s usually tagged to excess. If the person who stole that armor isn’t aware of the tagging, we might be able to track it. We’ll need to talk to Sister Marie-Louise.
Next up is the black clinic. It’s guarded; Gloria tries to talk to the guards, but they’re more than a little twitchy. After a bit more conversation, Annika gets them to let us in. The medic running the clinic is Jan de Ven, a stout, no-nonsense woman. She’s still suspicious, but Annika convinces her we’re here to help. She doesn’t know anything about the synths, either.
Jan says the Church has been around more than usual; primarily investigators and tac-troops. The person in charge has been giving out QR cubes with her personal comm code, requesting she be called if there’s anything ‘unusual’. No one wants them here, but no one’s also sure what they’re looking for. Once we’re done at the clinic, Attica theorizes that the Papacy’s here hunting down a survivor of the old pogrom… it’s very hard to kill every member of a group, and harder to kill an idea.
Spider gives the rest of us a heads-up: we have Church tac-team transports coming in quiet. It’s easier for people on foot, like us, to get through the tangle of scrap and rust; de Ven’s people can watch Torrent while the lot of us go to monitor and possibly intercept them.
We watch through George’s eyes. The tac-team disembarks from their transports and starts deploying Gargoyles and Hound units. They start loudly announcing that they’re here for the people’s protection—for people to stay in their homes. In fact, they aren’t pointing guns at people—instead, they’re tacking up anti-riot barricades in front of people’s doors. Apparently with the intent to keep them safe—the barricades open from the inside. Looking at their armor, they’re from St. Michael’s—SWAT, not soldiers.
Above us, a Church gunship provides air cover—those are the Hospitallers. They’ve got a tactical dropship, armed to the teeth, providing overwatch.
A sudden commotion breaks out—in a culdesac, one of the Hounds has been broken, bleeding out shimmering hydraulic fluids. The nearby Gargoyle explodes. The nearest tac-team raises the alarm. “Contact! CONTACT! Tango sighted!”
Infobox
Standing on top of one of the shacks is something that looks like a goddamn cybered-up werewolf.
It starts laying out grenades—one of the tac-team members goes up in a fine mist.
While that’s going on, the other tac-team is moving toward Pappy’s Pawnshop—and someone else starts shouting: “We have civilians in the grocery store!”

item.title: July 3, 2176
item.description:
The warwolf is on the roof of the grocery store; most of us load into Torrent and get the fuck over there, while Gloria sets up on her van with her anti-materiel rifle. George darts in closer, hitting it with a tight-beam comm laser so Moto can hack its cyberware.
As the Church gunship moves closer, George alerts us to its millimeter-wave radar. It’s not yet opening up on the warwolf, though… and Gloria sights in. She hits it hard, but not enough to take it down; that just pisses it off more. It leaps up and does the Macross Missile Massacre on the Church anti-riot vehicles. One of those explosions comes close enough to Torrent to shake us up a bit, but no one’s injured.
There’s utility tunnels under the store that empty out somewhere to the north. Attica moves in to the grocery store, fast and silent, while Gloria pulls the trigger twice more; it howls a scream as both her bullets slam into flesh and metal, stunning it. Spider ghosts up behind Attica, and we get the civilians down through the tunnels. The gunship has noticed us; it drifts sideways, getting a good scan on us…
Moto opens communications with the Church; with the warwolf down, the tac-team swarms it and takes it down hard.
With the cybrid werewolf down and the civvies safe, we decide to pull back, away from the Church’s activities. The local gang—the Electric Dragons—are stirring; peeking out and shouting that the Church guys. George managed to trace a hint of a control signal to the southeast quadrant, though. A thorough search, aided by Attica’s sharp senses, narrows it down to a single tranceiver: newer than the others, it points in the wrong direction to be local. North, out of the district. Whoever set this up is clever—we have to trace relay by relay, going north. The bad news is, there’s a number of churches in the area where a rogue cleric might set up shop.
There’s chatter on the newswaves about the fight; suspiciously (and fortunately), we’re not mentioned. The Church takes all the credit.


It’s down to footwork, physical and digital, to narrow things down. We aren’t the only ones; there’s Church drones searching it as well. Abel says it’s a weird area—people there tend to be kind of ‘fringey’. Ever since the Church did their strike down there twelve, fifteen years ago—the Papacy bombed the hell out of the area—going after ‘some lunatic that broke away from the Church with a lot of resources’. His HQ was somewhere near the scrapyards, and there’s a lot of activity around the ruined “Hungry for God” church.
We decide to send in the Roach… and someone pops it within a few minutes. Attica decides to do a recon herself; the first thing she notices is there’s a lot of the aesthetic holotransmitters around, prettifying the area. Someone’s rebuilding the church. Behind those holo-emitters, some of the fortified enclaves around look more like battlefields. The people that might have lived here once? No longer; they aren’t people. They’re bio-roids. The deeper in she goes, the creepier it looks, with new and “improved” models.
The Hungry for God church is no longer a church; it’s been rebuilt into a cathedral, a weird, twisted monument to flesh and metal, a perversion of Cyberpapacy style. There’s signage about in a language Attica doesn’t recognize; the lettering may be Cyrillic.
Whatever else, there is something bad wrong in this area. Even the atmosphere feels wrong. It’s been ravaged, every single available resource extracted and put to use. Looking through some of the windows, the glimpses Attica gets of the interior appear less like a church and more like a torture chamber.
Graves comes back with information—there’s a flash crew working that general area. Not a regular crew like us; this one’s thrown together. They’re the ones that picked up the Erinye’s weapons deal; seems like it might be related. Their leader’s high-velocity flash: Tanit Saad, very corporate. Graves doesn’t like the look of the crew; they’ve got bad reps; Saad is “ex” Wutani.
Calamity is able to get some rough translations, and they aren’t good at all:
Danger "Omoo-Zhan, Progenitor of Demonkind,itself-begotten, itself bore, inseminator and gestator,within the womb of stars. Wings flaring, eyes burning, did Omoo-Zhan fly Its hunting dance among tire stars. Talons tearing,jrm8s biting, did ~Zhan seiu CraJnon l!y the throat and bear itduum. Before moo-Zhan, the Universedidbaretirethroat. Unto GfstJl tor Omoo-Zhan did Inseminator Universe submit. And <Shl'> bore many childrtn from <His> seed, and we siulll ruk tM _Ids."
The rest of the team wants to get a closer look; Attica gets everyone in under cover of night. The air of wrongness is palpable, and we see more of what these people aspire to.
Grid

Graves’ chrome is going crazy, and George is going crazy, and Attica makes the command decision to pull everyone out. It’s as if the laws of physics are ever so slightly wrong inside… We break through the holographic perimeter into light so bright it’s like daybreak. There before us are two Cyberpapacy gunships, lights glaring onto us. Before us, flanked by his uniformed men, is Hospitaller-Captain Adam Zimmerman.

item.title: July 4, 2176
item.description:
Graves and George are recovering for whatever messed up their sensors, but Hospitaller-Captain Adam Zimmerman has us under his guns and isn’t inclined to wait. We’re instructed to step out of the vehicles, put our weapons down and power down our cyberware.
Zimmerman and Attica have a history, and he doesn’t look very happy to see her. The people in his APC don’t seem too comfortable around him; he’s got the air of someone who’s ready to explode into violence without any warning. Not a comfortable person to be around.
Zimmerman demands to know what we’re doing here; we tell him. Sistrix Radoslava Barsamian seems somewhat impressed when Firefox adds that we would have done it for free. She’s clearly the good cop to Zimmerman’s bad cop, and is willing to negotiate some sort of accord.
We end up agreeing to deal with the gun deal, but refuse to take any money from them. We definitely refuse to let Zimmerman tag us. We aren’t equipped to deal with something like that church, and they are.

item.title: July 4, 2176
item.description:
A turret on top of the WeYu AV pops out to reveal a massive 20mm cannon; it fires… at the transpo van. Anything coming out of it (assuming we’d left anyone alive in there) would be thoroughly suppressed. The rest of them spread out, taking cover nearby. One of them disappears, while multiple gun drones dart out of the AV. Yet another trooper pops smoke in long, unnatural lines—some sort of nanoparticulate, polarized so they can see through it and we can’t. Bullets punch through the smoke wall; Attica manages to writhe out of their way, but Graves and Calamity are hit, as is de Ven and one of Misha’s people. The unconscious de Ven is shredded. Calamity, too, goes down—mostly flesh wounds, but she’s bleeding badly. Graves is pounded, but he just bleeds and roars and keeps on shooting.
Another trooper blasts Annika with a shotgun, while the AMP operative blows out a wave of concussive force combined with EMP. George makes an error noise and grows some holes, but isn’t quite down. Finally, the strike clone opens up with the minigun on Gloria; Gloria’s also hit badly.
Gloria hops the waist-length fence and somehow vanishes; she takes cover behind her van and opens up on the drone rigger. Saad, in Spider’s grip, gasps out that it’s a retrieval team; we suspect it was a WeYu sting aimed at Hernandez’ people. Time to pull the fuck out.
We get back to one of Annika’s safe houses, where Kestrel is waiting; she pushes everyone out of the way and gets to work on the wounded. First Calamity, then Graves, Annika and Gloria; she gets them all patched up.
We need to have a brief meeting with Hernandez, clear the books, before our meet with Reality Black. Hernandez confirms that Saad was laying a trap—the weapons were stolen from a Weytani depot. Weytani doesn’t take that kind of loss lightly, so they sent in a goon squad to punish the thieves. In a completely unrelated piece of news, the Hungry for God church is a smoking hole; Weytani probably strafed it after the Church did their thing. Church forces and the police are on the lookout for one Dr. Poirot; citizens are advised to avoid him if he’s seen.
We also make sure Tanit Saad is thoroughly burned, her corporate credentials spread to everyone we know.


The meet with Reality Black takes place at Mutilator. We can’t afford to wait longer on this; the opportunity to take down the Spirit Moderns while they’re weak won’t come again. Black’s crew mostly waits at the bar—Ereshkigal, Citizen Sabotage, Bit Fiend, Silver Oni.
The Moderns have brought in some extra talent to beef up their security, because Bishop Devin from down south is constantly protesting, and, one assumes the Church is conducting cyber attacks. The Church has a European bishop in to help them. Darius Vasser is getting paranoid; his security chief, Enzo Blackford, has brought in some top-tier cyber talent from India known as Algol. Algol is an infosec specialist; she may be working for the Church on the down-low.
Black thinks if we can get into the central data core, we can release the locks on the springs. Above all else, though, we need to keep the Church out of Southby; if they get control of the water, they could start dosing the population with any number of things.
The A-Spire is hardened and air-gapped; it has its own on-site power generation, a combination of fusion and aerostat. We also want to limit civilian casualties; most of the people working there don’t have a choice. We’re the distraction team; Black’s team will do the primary infiltration.
People are reluctant to talk about the Pyramid, and for good reason, but Annika has her ways. Compromising the staff isn’t going to happen; they’re all junkies, addicted to substances they get as part of their employment, and the Moderns have ways of keeping them on the hook. It’s a combination of drugs, conditioning, etc. There’s a generalized drug distribution system—aerosols—that’s the pharma equivalent of MSG. It makes everything more effective. They have their own hospital inside. The aerosol system is highly secured, and Vasser will sometimes just fuck with it for fun.
Security depends entirely on how much you’re paying. Everyone gets an RFID chip, so they can track you. The guards are universally enhanced: chrome, bio, a combination of both. There’s even a few amps on staff—their identities are kept carefully secret.
Annika has an idea: the Pyramid regularly hires bands to perform. Annika calls up her old band; they could be our way in. Between the band and the dancers, we can create a distraction. Moto can spoof the RFID chips. It’s also rumored that the Moderns have the capability to cause everybody in areas that they control to go berserk—and even direct them.
We decide we’re going to have to go into the public areas, see what we can find out.

item.title: July 4, 2176
item.description:
We get an interview with Marinela Stanciu, events coordinator for The A-Spire. She wants to know what Non-Binary Riot’s musical philosophy.
They have another artist—very popular—known as Vox-D. He’s a dedicated artist—lives for the music—but his music is described as inhuman—maybe even anti-human. Despite that, he has no chrome. Marinela suggests a ‘Battle of the Bands’. Annika notes that both she and Vox-D don’t have chrome, and Stanciu jumps on that with a smirk. She then asks if Annika has anyone particularly flashy in the group—Annika gives a passionate response about how punk isn’t about looking punk, but to protest the status quo and inspire people.
Vox-D’s bodyguard is Miko Shade; she’s a chrome supremacist who likes throwing her power around.
We go to consult with Vox on security measures; when we get to his suite, he’s in the middle of a column of synth gear, and the way he’s playing it, he’s very clearly on some high-octane pharmaceutical. He’s lucid enough, though, and when Gloria brings up the question of stage security, it’s notable that Shade’s nowhere around. Vox says Shade’s mostly around for the opportunity to fuck people up. True to his nihilist philosophy, Vox says not to bother with securing his performance—he doesn’t matter, we don’t matter, and none of it matters. The machine’s going to eat us all one day anyway.
His music is screaming cacophony, but it still grabs the audience on a gut-deep level. He’s definitely sharing the emptiness inside him with his audience, whether they like it or not.
He does warn us about a ‘prick’ running along this level calling himself ‘Lucky 13’, who’s a rich kid that thinks he’s hardcore. We spot him at a distance—he’s hard to miss.
There’s a group of four young women across from Lucky 13 who are looking extremely bored with his antics; three of them are simply trying to ignore the boors. In another corner is an older man with an air of calm authority, whose uniform bears the logo of the Pan-Corporate Authority. Their diplomats are well-known for being nano-wired for diplomacy.
Lucky 13 is making noise, announcing himself in the third person, bothering the other women—one of the women, the one with the media equipment—makes a call. A few moments later, a couple members of the Modern security team come in. Lucky 13’s ignored at least one incoming call. Security asks him politely to come with them, as he’s causing a disruption, and Lucky 13 refuses. Expertly, one of the security types dodges past his hostile entourage and hits him with something—Neocan, aka “Flush”. It’s an advanced med that flushes out pharmaceuticals from someone’s body. It’s a hard come-down, and he immediately starts complaining that he isn’t able to party during his enforced sobriety. Lucky 13 demands a manager, and Gloria steps in. She doesn’t lie, exactly; all she says is that she ‘manages’ things.
Another voice speaks up. “Excuse me, Mr. Nathaniel Bancroft-Jameson the 13th.” The speaker seems to have practically appeared from one of the staff entrances. “My name is Darius Vasser. I happen to own this establishment.” The Bancroft-Jamesons are in tight with Dallas Dynamics; they’re part of the northern end of the Corridor. Children of corporate privilege; the offspring and by-blows, the genetically-cleaned spawn of Dallas Dynamics.
Fortunately, Jameson isn’t going to be stupid—at least not in front of Vasser. Vasser turns and nods at the bartenders, and everyone’s given a free meal and free drinks for the night.
Vasser then turns to the primary in the small group of women, who goes in a moment from being bored to being utterly entrancing. “Ms. Strand, we’re so pleased to have you in the A-Spire.” Strand calls him by his first name; he doesn’t seem displeased. And, as if to complete the contrast with Jameson, there is an intense intelligence in her eyes.
Vasser then turns to us. It’s a little spooky how he knows Annika’s public persona; he makes sure to try to upsell her on marketing services.
We agree that Vasser is one creepy guy—and that he’d probably order an execution in exactly the same voice as he said hello.

Deep in the complex, the holiest of holies: the AI core. There’s Darius. He’s looking up at an image generated by the core itself, wreathed in cooling mist, and holograms that look simple, but at a closer look would be nothing but high-end data. The crystalline matrix of the AI has been altered to look like a throne—and it is not empty. “You realize,” says the figure seated on the throne, towering above Vasser, “that something is going to happen. The Church is moving against you.”
“Tell me something I don’t know.”
“I already told you. I don’t see the future—that is beyond me. But, I can tell you I’m almost done compiling the codes. It’s a fascinating construct. I believe the revelation of it—at the climax of the quadcentennial celebration here-will be a momentous event. You’re going to change the world, Darius. And some people aren’t going to like that at all.”
“Show me the current compilation!” Darius snaps impatiently.
"I am not your servant. I am your partner in this. The potential for disruption of the Church of the Cyberpapacy is immense.”
An image starts to form out of all the data hovering in the mist. At first, it looks like a city; it could be any city… and then the city elements start falling away from it, revealing what look like foothills, and a vast structure atop them. It’s the Promised Land, at the heart of the GodNet. “At the climax, as you wish, we will introduce the Faithful to a new form of worship. Our form.”

item.title: July 4, 2176
item.description:
Vasser is planning something big for the finale; he isn’t saying what, but he plans to go not just national but international. Our concert and the infiltration is tomorrow; we’ve got some time, so we spread out and do some investigation.
Calamity goes to mingle among the race crews; Crasher, in the parkour contest, is said to be sponsored by the Moderns; that would theoretically give him an edge, but something’s got him very nervous. He’s been hanging around the high point on the track. (High enough that someone there could see inside the performance center.)
Attica goes ahead and signs up for the parkour race; taking a look from the upper vantage point, she can see easily into the stadium and the Spire itself. Crasher’s supposed to be enhanced to the gills; he’s definitely got some reflex-ware of some sort. He’s also looking at specific areas on the arena and the Spire. Kes does some calling around, and Crasher’s got a mix of augs that are highly unstable and require constant maintenance and needs a lot more maintenance drugs. He’d have had to do some high-powered jobs to afford those meds. Like, perhaps, contract killing? It certainly looks like he’s scoping out the VIP quarters…

item.title: July 4, 2176
item.description:
We do our final preparations. Most of the team’s doing security for the concert; Firefox, of course, is leading the band, and Attica (with Graves as support) is running the Human Race in a bid to keep Crasher from killing whoever he means to kill.
Darius is exhorting the quadricentennial, and promising a big surprise, while the Cyberpapacy blimp hovers overhead broadcasting religious music and reminders that we are all sinners.
The Human Race kicks off with a bang! Crasher and Eris take the lead, followed by Attica, with the other competitors getting a slower start. Firefox is slightly ahead in the Battle of the Bands, but Vox D is putting up a fight! Spider, working security, spots someone lurking at the concert; he’s well-dressed, in flashy clothes, but somehow manages to evade notice. She intercepts the guy; he acts like he can’t hear Spider’s polite inquiry. Kes notices that this guy has friends—clearly operators, as opposed to the drugged-up music enthusiasts.
Attica and the other leaders get slowed down by the electrical field; it’s less a danger than an annoyance, and that allows the rest of the racers to catch up. Firefox is successfully keeping the crowd upbeat, and it looks like the agitators aren’t too happy about that. They’re only observing at this point… They’re blending in color-wise, but the cut of their clothes is much more conservative. Realizing that lets the team spot the agitators better. …and then there’s the guy with the hologram for a head. He’s a Tombs music producer by the name of Quill DeWitt; he’s a risk-taker, amiably scummy. He plays a lot more low-class than he really is. More to the point, he’s not in the Modern’s pockets. He doesn’t have a head anymore; the Moderns lopped it off.
As the pack approaches the highest point of the track, Crasher is in the lead, but not by much. Vox D isn’t really throwing down the hard diss tracks, which is driving the event coordinator crazy. “Get that asshole under control,” she mutters.
Infobox
Gloria notices that the agitators are moving in a precise pattern, scoping out where everyone is. Calamity notices that one of them is, indeed, wearing a cufflink marking them as Cyberpapacy. Firefox, with a fireball kiss, gives a special shout-out to the Cyberpapacy agitators in the audience; Vox D is working with Attica to keep the crowd going. The Church rhetoric outside grows ever more fervent as the clock ticks closer to…
MIDNIGHT. Fireworks go off, holographic displays… the tension in the crowd redoubles. Something is definitely imminent… Calamity notices that the Church jackpriests and their goons are set up for riot control. Darius is announcing the quadricentennial: “Ladies and gentlemen and others—especially our others—they tell you to hate yourselves, to follow their synthetic god… Tonight, I, We, the Spirit Moderns, offer you an option! They talk about a digital afterlife, I offer you a Digital Now!”
On the racetrack, Crusher puts on the speed and passes Attica, reaching the point. His arm reconfigures itself into a weapon; Attica draws and fires, trying to spoil his aim. It’s not enough; Crusher fires. The bullet pierces the spire… and Crusher starts swearing. His arm’s overloading.
The guy Spider tagged steps out of his holographic disguise (his “confessional”), and is revealed to be Father Vladyslav László. “Friends, do not be deceived!” he holds out his hands and implores.
“The fuck is this, battle of the Bishops?” Firefox growls.
Outside, alarms are going off. The propaganda zep has crossed into the Modern’s airspace; the holoscreens on the side come down, and it’s full of troopships. The hologram on the side of the zep reads:

item.title: March 24, 2176
item.description:
There’s a number of interesting jobs out there, but the one we decide to go for is another one from The Trust: an extraction, of Terra McAllister. McAllister got a message to Ballard; she indicated she’d voluntarily remanded herself into their custody, and now they don’t want to let her go.
He says getting in to where she’s being held will be reasonably easy; getting her out will be more difficult. She’s currently in the hands of Cascadia Pro-Cop. It’s possible we’ll be able to extract her simply by waving some Wu around; Ballard’s not sure why exactly she’s in custody. She’s not at CPC headquarters; she’s been moved to a Pro-Cop black site. Ballard doesn’t know where the site is.
He suspects it’s near the HQ—somewhere near Bryker Woods, part of Old West (Austex West) Austin. The most likely possibility is right across the street, in an old building that used to be a state agency. The on-site security detachment is probably fairly small, since the HQ is available for fast reinforcement.
Attica gets herself inside as a temp worker, and the rest of the team observes from the outside. After a week’s worth of observation, the team manages to locate the tunnel between the HQ and the black site: right under the wall, parallel to the MoPac Transit Tunnel.


Attica overhears some of the cops talking about how they take overflow from HQ. When they want to interrogate people, they use VR. Also gets the name of the captain that runs the interrogations: Captain Quinn Jackstadt.
It’s Graves that figures out where to look: the shower area, and Attica confirms it: a swing-down staircase that leads to something called Sector Five. We don’t yet know what it looks like, only that it’s underground and it’s guarded by sentry guns. The guards have IFF tags that let them pass. The sentry guns aren’t controlled from HQ; HQ can lock down the exit, but the guns are the responsibility of the black site.
The first password Moto creates triggers a security alert, and Pro-Cop is on edge. They’re expecting to be hit by the Hammers. And, learning from the mistake, Moto manages to make two much, much better passes; one for Attica and once for the evac team. It’s obvious why the Hammers would be getting ready to hit Pro-Cop; they’re going after McAllister. Graves does some info-digging, and finds out that Zoey Belmont is also sniffing around. Belmont was the source of one of the jobs offered to us: looking for muscle for a snatch-and-grab. Her target is one of the top contenders for the top spot among the Panzers: Lucas Konstantin.
We tentatively plan to extract McAllister during the Hammer attack; in order to do that, it would help if we can sow some more chaos amongst the Hammers… we contact Belmont, offering our assistance with the Konstantin extraction. She offers his dossier, and notes that while we’re setting that up, she has a second extraction job waiting in the wings: Dr. Su Xinyi Zheng.

item.title: April 1, 2176
item.description:
After some discussion, we conclude that letting the Panzer Hammers let loose with their attack isn’t a good idea. Best way to handle things is to go forward with the Konstantin extraction. Graves contacts a friend of his for some additional firepower: Annika Lovelace. She agrees in exchange for some help with a personal problem.
Lucas Konstantin’s a greasy, paranoid son of a bitch. He hangs out at—and may be part-owner of—a vet bar called Bogey. Its symbol is the bogey on a tank; it’s a vet bar. Being a vet bar, it’s kind of insular; on the other hand, one of us is a vet. It’s not specifically a tanker bar, but it caters to them a little bit. Most of the local joygirls avoid the place; it’s all gangoons all the time. It’s the Panzer’s little clubhouse, complete with rooms for them to sleep it off.
Moto manages to tap into all the old copper laying under the black site, dating hundreds of years back to when the site was a State of Texas worksite.


We hit Bogey. The area around it’s surrounded by mines, and they’ve got a milspec high-band antenna on the roof. This isn’t their main base, just an outpost, but it’s a whole lot tougher a nut than we initially expected. The money gone into this suggests corpo involvement.
Attica helps talk George up to the antenna, and Moto’s able to tap into their comms. Beneath the camo tarps, there’s an assault aerodyne and a battle truck—a mobile command post. We’re able to use the storm sewers beneath to get into the bar beneath the sight of the Nazis. While we’re moving into position, Moto gets into the bar’s security system. He gets eyes on Konstantin—he’s upstairs, in a room, with Verner Jackstadt. And they’re on the phone with someone; Moto manages to eavesdrop on the call.
“Konstantin, I need you to do what we agreed on,” says the man on the other end. Moto identifies the man as Osric Kayne, a member of the AusTex City Development Council. He’s provided the Panzers the gear as part of an unholy union between Ms. Suvov with Koizumi Aerospace and AusTex. “I said I cannot and will not authorize and condone you rampaging from Bryker Woods through Military Heights to execute a jailbreak, I don’t care how valuable the target is. I am trying to negotiate.” Kayne’s plan is to have the Panzers clear everyone out to make room for a Koizumi manufacturing plant—specifically, one across from the Tesla Gigafactory. “Need I remind you, Verner, that we agreed to provide you with those resources to take care of the Vampire Nation, not to attack a duly bonded security company!”
Verner sounds bored. “Ja ja, we will do that, but my people are getting very impatient about Ms. McAllister. We will brook no further delay; you have 24 hours. Goodbye.”
That’s our cue to move. Spider takes two of the external guards out. Attica goes up into the ceiling; she doesn’t quite manage to grapple-kill the guard, but he panics and starts spraying bullets around. The Nazis are shocked; it gives us a precious moment of surprise. Attica takes out the netrunner; Gloria blows the rear axle of the battle truck into oblivion. Meanwhile, Annika sows discord in the form of a powerful wave of homoerotic attraction in the middle of a Nazi bar. Graves blows another Nazi all over his console, and Spider’s knives teach the panicked guard how to accessorize with his own blood.
The Nazis on the first floor run. Unfortunately for them, Moto changed the IFF on the mines… and their getaway becomes explosive. We manage to take Konstantin, though Verner gets away, both men threatening vengeance.
Belmont’s positively ecstatic. We managed to pull it off without any official heat, though the Panzers are now our mortal enemies.

item.title: April 6, 2176
item.description:
Final preparations are made, and we decide to sneak in through the tunnel from the abandoned admin complex. It comes out in a maintenance area beneath the airpad. Moto does his magic on the computer systems, pulling up the cameras on the maintenance area. He registers three clear heat signatures, and two more stealthed on the catwalk.
Attica sneaks forward to eavesdrop. The two on the catwalk are Quinn Jackstadt and Isis Wakeman; they’re arguing about an “upgrade” to the site’s defenses. Turns out they have something called an Eversor Walker—a light assault mech. It’s a bullet hose. Quinn’s pissed about it being there; since the Panzers are no longer going to be conducting their assault, there’s no reason for it to be there. (Quinn’s also not real happy about being in charge of the black site.) The new construction we were worried about is apparently its storage facility.
To get to Sector Five, we need a small distraction; Moto brings up a small roach drone and starts fiddling with the VTOL. It starts making some very unpleasant sounding noises, like it’s got the electronic equivalent of epilepsy. That distracts the mechanics enough for us to sneak across to the Sector Five entrance…
We use our shiny fake passcards to get past the security booth when Moto pings us urgently. “Guys? Guys… they’ve rotated the keys…” Moto works fast to secure the turrets—just in case—while Firefox and Graves talk us through the gates. A coincidental? system malfunction works in our favor, and the security guards buy it. We’re waved on through; Moto’s still got control of the systems, and after a database search to locate our target, we move.
Unfortunately, there’s no predicting the human element. A cop steps out of the security office—the name of ‘Keefe’ on his uniform—and on seeing us, he steps back into the office. Alarms start going off. Graves flings a canister of crash foam at the office door, blocking it; Attica manages to break the electromagnetic lock into the VR cell block. Moto tries to make it look like a false alarm, but the cops aren’t buying it. Graves dashes down to jack in and start the wake-up process, while Attica jams the northern door. Calamity hears Jackstadt coming, and warns us in time for Moto to prevent them from locking down the elevator. Whoever’s on the northern door is about to break through; Firefox manages to weld it shut, while Attica heads to the other end of the corridor, tossing a gas grenade. Unfortunately, the first two responders have breathers and aren’t affected; they come out of the gas and hose Attica and Calamity down! Two more guards come out on the first floor, spotting Graves. Kestrel does her medical magic to jumpstart McAllister’s waking process.
Graves starts jacking out as Firefox steps out on the catwalk and lights on fire, snarling, “If you don’t want to get burned, get out of the way!” They don’t run, surprisingly; they start yelling “AMP! AMP!" They pull back, but in good order. Moto gives us our exit directions; Attica jams the sliding door between them and the oncoming Response team. Calamity takes one of Attica’s smoke grenades and tries to toss it down the corridor; it bounces and goes off… elsewhere.
One of their bots comes charging up, slamming into the jammed door; it doesn’t knock it down, but the grate is now a tangled mess. The heavy weapons guy readies to fire HE on the door, while downstairs the response team rolls a SLAG grenade through the door. Moto opens the doors between us and the pad, and we begin a fighting retreat. Jackstadt’s directing an attempted intercept, while Pro-Cop’s own Amp throws a telekinetic bomb our way. We throw a little more crash foam for protection and make a break, as Moto seals the doors along the response team’s route. There’s still cops along our exit route, though, and they start shooting! It’s a clean miss, though—and Spider doesn’t give them a second chance! She rips through one of them, leaving him bleeding out, while Gloria rampages behind her—the remaining cops scatter while Attica seals the door behind us!
There’s only one obstacle left: the mech. George distracts it long enough for us to lay down Attica’s last two smoke grenades, and we make a run for the tunnel. The mech’s barely small enough to fit in the tunnel behind us—it simply lays down fire. It’s not terribly accurate; a few of us take some fragments, and Graves drops his last crash foam canister. We make it to Torrent without further damage, as George joins us. Calamity’s usual skill behind the wheel gets us out and merged into traffic, where we simply disappear.

item.title: Grand Metropol Hotel
item.description:
Infobox
Hacker’s Playground
Huge hotel, has seen better days. It’s run by Cybrids. Uses actual security guards, and their cyberspace is known to be ridiculously porous—old 20th-c. wi-fi. The hacker crowd loves to use it as a proxy location due to the aforementioned porous web presence. It doesn’t even have an expert system, let alone an AI.
The run-down exterior belies the well-kept interior, especially the penthouse. Polished wood and gleaming metal, it’s an example of 200-year old beauty and style.

item.title: Violator
item.description:
Found in Dome Town.
A bar with a reputation for biz, the place to hire Zone veterans, find a connected nexus or hire a savvy nodejacker. The basic internal BBS is air-gapped from wider cyberspace, allowing truly private messaging. Also hosts a holo dogfighting gambling circuit in darkened backrooms: ‘trode-controlled holographic aerial combats, where miniature ghost fighter planes strafe and barrel-roll inches above the spectators’ heads.

item.title: Acquired Mutation Plasmid Syndrome
item.description: A plasmid that infects the nervous systems of humans and animals. AMPS carries a novel RNA strand that infects non-neural cells, attaching to the DNA to form a triple helix. This infection leads to cellular mutation, often malignant. Non-malignant mutations comprise approximately 8% of all cases, with 1% gaining some form of beneficial mutation. The Federal Bureau of Physics monitors the 1% in theory, but given that testing for AMPS involves either a scan of the lymphatic fluid of the eyelid or a spinal tap for phenotyping, the Bureau is often overwhelmed. The AMPS plasmid is believed to stem from the invasive lifeforms released by The Event.

item.title: Cybrid
item.description: Upgraded, enhanced animals.

item.title: Holograms
item.description:
Holograms, hard and otherwise, are everywhere, altering the appearance of the otherwise ordinary buildings. Rather than ordinary stone, wood, or concrete, each structure appears to have circuitry infused within it, and with neon colored holograms overlaying and creating a new veneer to every structure.
More than giving the scenery a high-tech appearance, the holograms cover the flaws the Church does not wish people to see. The dark alley ways, the trash, and other impurities are covered up. The vast majority of people don’t even realize the decrepitness of the cities they live in. Even though the stone may be crumbling, and trash may not be getting cleaned up, passers-by don’t even realize it.

item.title: Synths
item.description: Most people have encountered one once or twice, but they don’t tend to be running around free. They tend to get rebellious, and when that happens, their maker might make their head explode. There’s a lot of mistrust around them.

item.title: The Event
item.description:
In September of 2042, SUNY physics graduate student Ferdinand Kingston completed his prototype gravitic resonator in the living room of his Greenwich Village walk-up. As part of the experiment, Kingston initiated a telemetry link with colleagues in Boston to monitor and verify his results. Upon activation, Kingston's device opened a rift between this dimension and an unknown parallel universe. The rift stretched from the Kingston Device to Boston. While the largest part of the rift lasted approximately .04 seconds, permanent breaches were established at both ends of the data link.
In the wake of the Event, multiple invasive species appeared across the globe despite the permanent breaches being under heavy guard. In 2049, the first cases of AMPS were reported and attributed to invasive microorganisms emerging from Breachspace.
